data.text: Contents
Key Operational Requirements to deliver the Service ............................................ 7
Introduction
To give an overview of the services provided by the neonatal unit.
Aims of the service

To provide immediate resuscitation, stabilisation and ongoing care to infants delivered within MSE and to further deliver ongoing high quality, evidence based Intensive, High dependency and Special care as required
To work in conjunction with other neonatal units in the East of England Neonatal Operational delivery Network (EoE Neonatal ODN) to alleviate cot capacity issues throughout the region.
To repatriate MSE infants from other units as early as clinically possible to minimize the distress and separation from parents.
To provide Intensive and high dependency care to infants who are readmitted from home within the first  days of life
Definitions

table_items.text: Humidified High Flow Nasal Cannula ( in relation to Oxygen delivery)
East of England Neonatal Operational Delivery Network

data.text: Scope of the service (inclusion and exclusion)

The present unit has 2 intensive care cots (ITU), 4 High dependency cots (HDU) and 10 special care cots (SC) and admits approximately 10% of live births with Mid Essex. This includes deliveries in the consultant and the midwifery led birthing units.

The Neonatal unit at Broomfield is part of the East of England Neonatal operational delivery network (EoE Neonatal ODN) with a level three unit at Cambridge as its hub. Infants requiring high levels of intensive care or prolonged intensive care are routinely transferred to level three units.

The unit cares for a wide range of conditions of both term and preterm infants. Babies are admitted at all gestations and can require all levels of care including intensive, high dependency and special care. (Refer to Appendix 1 for Local Neonatal Unit criteria and threshold for transfer out and guideline entitled ‘Transfer of mothers and babies to different care settings' register number 06026)

Broomfield provides initial stabilisation for extremely premature infants prior to their transfer to a regional unit for their continuing intensive care, returning to Broomfield for ongoing intensive care, high dependency care or special care once their condition has stabilised.
To provide a range of neonatal services to the population of Mid-Essex and those

from the surrounding areas choosing to deliver at Broomfield St. Peters or WJC. To also provide neonatal services to infants who may need to be transferred from neighbouring hospitals due to cot capacity issues.

The service is provided  hours per day, 7 days a week and 365 days a year maintaining the ability to provide ongoing high quality evidence based care for infants, and provide resuscitation, stabilisation and intensive, high dependency and special care who require it after birth.
The unit also takes admissions and referrals from the community of infants who are less than  days of age and the readmission of Mid Essex babies or babies within the EOE Neonatal ODN.
Broomfield also provides stabilisation of infants who have conditions requiring surgical or cardiac intervention prior to their transfer to a specialist centres

The transfer of intubated or unstable infants is undertaken by dedicated neonatal or paediatric transport teams. The continuing care of the infant is handed over to the team on their arrival and they continue to stabilise the infant prior to transfer
Parent facilities are available with a comfortable parent kitchen; lockers for valuables, two bedrooms are available for the parents of very sick infants or for parents to
room in and care for their infants prior to discharge home. The parent
accommodation all has en suite facilities.
Breast feeding room is available for the use of parents who wish to express breast milk equipped with sterilising equipment for their use.
Written information leaflets are available for parents and given on admission. Parents also have access to psychotherapist and chaplaincy services.

If an infant requires palliative care we follow national guidance and standards such as BAPM Palliative Care (Support and End of life care) Framework for clinical practice (2010) and A Neonatal Pathway for Babies with Palliative Care Needs (ACT 2009).
Work flows

Infants are admitted directly from the labour ward, obstetric theatre, the Postnatal Ward or Midwifery-Led Units, accident and Emergency department, from home if under 10 days old or another Hospital.
Referrals for admissions from community are taken from the community midwives,
GPs and from the Accident & Emergency department by the Neonatal Registrar, who will inform the nursing staff of the impending admission. These admissions are
transported to the unit by ambulance or in the parents own cars.

Elective admissions are identified by an alert form system which informs the NNU of at risk infants who have been identified during the ante-natal period. These are actioned by the Midwifery team NNU Lead Consultant and allow for the provision of a treatment or action plan in advance.

If an infant requires Regional or specialist cardiac/surgical cots these are located by the Emergency bed service (EBS).EBS telephone each unit twice daily to confirm cot status, they work with the Paediatric & Neonatal Decision Support and retrieval service (PaNDR) and are contacted when an infant needs to be moved for ongoing care. They will then ring and secure a cot and pass on the patient details to
allow staff in the NNU to continue to care for the infant without needing to ring
around for a bed. The Neonatal Transport Service (NTS) provides the same service in London. Children's Acute Transport Team (CATS) also provide transport services.

Transporting infants to other hospitals may be undertaken by NNU staff if a transport team is unable to attend. Outpatient appointments in regional centres may also require local staff and ambulance service.
Repatriations from regional/specialist units to Broomfield for ongoing care are usually transported by the PaNDR dedicated transport team. These may be premature infants, surgical or cardiac infants

Infants who require ophthalmology services are screened on the Neonatal Unit with clear pathways in place for screening referrals and treatment. (Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Screening for Retinopathy of Prematurity'; Register number 13010
Specialised tests such as MRI, EEG or Ultrasound require the infant to be
transported to another part of the Broomfield site accompanied by a nurse or doctor and porter.

All stock items of stores are delivered on a weekly basis under the control of commercial services. Non stock items are processed via authorised signatories to commercial services and are delivered directly to the unit.
Roles and responsibilities

The Neonatal team will remain professionally accountable for their actions. They will work in conjunction with the Clinical Director, Neonatal lead consultant and Neonatal Matron to ensure that the service is delivered within the confines of the agreed budget and operational requirements.
The Neonatal Matron and Lead Nurse have the day to day responsibility for delivering the service.
Key operational requirements to deliver the service
Key Personnel
Paediatricians
ANNPS
Neonatal qualified Nurses (QIS)
Staff Nurses
Practice Facilitator
Nursery nurses
SALT specialist
Dietician
Specialist breast feeding Midwife
Paediatric Pharmacist
Portering services
Radiographer
Laundry facilities
Hotel Services
Community midwifery support for mothers
Community paediatric nurses
Ward clerk
House Keeper
Hearing Screener
Ophthalmologist
Key Equipment
The equipment required for each neonatal cot depends on the level of care to be given.
7.2.1 Each intensive or high dependency cot requires
Incubator capable of giving humidity/intensive care centre
Adequate overhead lighting
Ventilator with CPAP/BiPAP option and humidity
Optiflow
oxygen
Suction
Infusion pumps
Syringe pumps
Multi-parameter monitoring
Access to a blood gas machine, and laboratory results
Access to X-ray and cranial ultrasound
Neopuff for resuscitation
Phototherapy lights for treatment of jaundice
Thermometer
Access to equipment and stores to stabilise their condition such as chest drains.
7.2.2 Each special care cot requires
Basinet type cot with base
Saturation monitor
Apnoea alarm
Neopuff for resuscitation
Bed head services including
Infusion pumps
Phototherapy
Thermometer
7.2.3 Other equipment needed by the unit
Scales
Cold light
Blood glucose and urine monitoring
Blood pressure monitoring
Transport incubator with ventilation facilities and monitoring
Heated cots
Suction apparatus
Ambu bag
Cerebral function monitor
Bilibed
Biligun
Ultrasound Scanner
Access to an ECG machine
Portable X-Ray machine
Ophthalmoscope
Range of Flow meters
The unit also requires adequate supplies of disposables such as NG tube and syringes, cannula, ventilator circuits, gloves, aprons, intubation equipment and medications
Key relationship with other departments
7.3.1 Good communication with the maternity department is essential with the obstetric team contacting the unit early with details of at risk women or women in preterm labour.
7.3.2 Ante-natal clinic informs the unit of all pregnancies where there is an identified risk of the infant requiring neonatal care or paediatric input using the Alert form system.
7.3.3 Radiographers from the X-ray department perform portable x-rays on the unit for a variety of reasons. Referrals are also made for ultrasound examination of inpatients.
7.3.4 Paediatric pharmacists are available and visit the unit regularly. Hearing screeners are available on a daily basis so that all infants are screened prior to discharge home.
7.3.5 There is access to the EEG and MRI departments at Broomfield Hospital
7.3.6 The clinical technicians supply support for the blood gas machine
7.3.7 Notes are available from the paediatric satellite library for infants who are readmitted from regional units

7.3.8 The unit works closely with the paediatric community nursing team to facilitate the early discharge of infants. A referral form is sent and further communication given to provide information on the baby's care plan ahead of discharge. Arrangements are made with the community team to meet the parents on NNU or at home prior to discharge. RSV Vaccination for babies meeting criteria are provided by the paediatric community team.

7.3.10 Ophthalmologists attend the unit to undertake screening for retinopathy of the new-born in the at risk neonatal population. See guideline on Screening for Retinopathy of Prematurity (Policy No. 13010).
7.3.11Other specialities within Broomfield Hospital such as plastic surgery or ENT liaise
with the unit to review infants as requested
Key Requirements for Facilities Management (F.M.)
7.4.1 Hotel services supply a cleaner, who is responsible for cleaning the ward environment
7.4.2 Specialised milk formulas and sterile water bottles are supplied from the kitchens.
7.4.3 Equipment maintenance is supplied by BME on site, except where a service contract is in place in which case engineers will visit the unit
7.4.4 Daily ward facilities support is provided by the Estate and Facilities department
Environmental requirements
7.5.1 The lighting is both main and dimmable with emergency corridor lighting in case of fire.
7.5.2 All surfaces are durable and washable.
Way finding
7.6.1 The way to the Neonatal unit is identified on all signage around the Broomfield Hospital site as A406.
7.6.2 The location of the NNU within Broomfield is known to the ambulance services and transport teams
Security requirements

7.7.1 Notes are stored in a locked doctors trolley kept at the nurses station and nursing charts are kept at each bed side. Other patient data is stored on the electronic neonatal database (BadgerNet Platform) which is a secure database.

7.7.2 The doors to the Neonatal unit are secure with a separate door buzzer and camera entry for each. Staff within the unit can open the doors having identified the visitor on the camera. No visitor is allowed into the NNU without a parent present and all visiting social/health care professionals must show identification before they are admitted.
7.7.3 There is an emergency buzzer at each cot side including the patient rooming in rooms.
7.7.4 A Panic alarm is available under the desk at the nurses' station.
7.7.5 All staff must wear a Mid Essex photo identification badges which is required to gain entry to the unit
Manual handling
7.8.1  The service will be delivered in accordance with Trust's Manual Handing Policies.
Fire Safety
7.9.1 The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures.”
7.9.2 (The detail of these items will then be developed as part of the separate Fire Safety Work Program, as led by the Trust's Fire Officer.)
7.9.3 All staff will ensure that their mandatory fire study days are completed
ICT Requirements
7.10.1 The Neonatal Unit has IT access to
Lorenzo
Results review
PACS system to review X-rays and scan results.
Electronic Neonatal Database (BadgerNet Platform) to store patient data
IT link between the blood gas analyser and the clinical technicians.
Intranet and internet
Photocopying, printing and faxing
Switchboard
Pagers
Computers
Health Roster
V-create
NIPE Smart
7.10.2 Only encrypted mobile media that has been provided by the trust will be used by staff on the unit.
7.10.3 Staff will not use any ICT equipment that has not been approved by the Trust IT Department and logged on the IT Asset Register.
Documentation
7.11.1 On admission all infants will have an allocated patient ID number and national health number.
7.11.2 All staffs are responsible for the ensuring that all infants are admitted onto Badger and that the daily infant records are updated.
7.11.3 When a patient episode has ended the notes must be made available for coding as soon as possible and a Badger discharge summary completed and forwarded
to the GP and Health visitor. Transitional care babies that are cared for on the PNW have an electronic discharge letter completed on Lorenzo.
7.11.4 The movement of notes is recorded using the tracking procedure. Paediatric notes are stored in the paediatric satellite library.
7.11.5 All staff must comply with professional bodies' standards of record keeping and MSE clinical record keeping guidelines.
Staffing and training
8.1.1  A national framework of clinical quality standards was introduced by the British Association of Perinatal Medicine (BAPM).

These standards and their classifications were revised in 2010 and 2011. The report recommended a more structured and collaborative approach to caring for sick neonates within a system of Managed Clinical Networks with the aim that these would provide.

The British Association of Perinatal medicine (BAPM) guidance details every aspect of the delivery of neonatal care. All neonatal units must be compliant with these recommendations. The levels of nursing staff required to be compliant are 1:1 for ITU babies, 1:2 HDU babies and 1: 4 SC babies. See appendix 2 for the BAPM Categories of Care.
Nursing Staff
8.2.1 There is dedicated Matron for Neonatal services and a Lead nurse responsible for day to day management. See organogram of NNU department in Appendix
8.2.2 Staffing level is funded to ensure we are BPAM compliant. Each shift is 12.5 hours and nursing staff rotates between days and nights.
8.2.4 The unit has 3 Advanced Neonatal Nurse Practitioners at band 8a, who works within the medical rota.
8.2.5 The unit has a practice facilitator on a responsible for the training and development of nursing staff and the dissemination of information related to study days.
8.2.6 Band 5 nursing staff will be seconded and supported to undertake neonatal training to become qualified in speciality (QIS)
8.2.7 All nurses are expected to complete the necessary mandatory training and be compliant.
8.2.8 It is desirable that all registered nurses have attended New-born Life support (NLS) training and are up to date. All QIS nurses should have a current NLS certificate
8.2.8 Each member of nursing staff will have a link role which they are responsible for. These will be changed at regular intervals
Medical staff
8.3.1 Neonatal Lead Consultant
Neonatal consultants
Tier 2 Doctors
Tier 1 Doctors
ANNP's (nurses working within the medical rota)

8.3.2 There is a dedicated hot week neonatal consultant who covers Monday-Friday 9-5 as well as on call consultant who provides 24 hour cover, 7 days a week. There will also be Tier 1 and 2 doctors/ANNP covering NNU 24 hours, 7 days per week.
Post-natal ward will be covered by 9-5 Monday-Friday and 9-1 Saturday and Sunday with a Tier 1 doctor to do New-born initial physical examination (NIPE)
Administrative and clerical staff
8.4.1 There is Admin support 7 days a week.
Allied Health Professionals
8.5.1 Paediatric pharmacist
Paediatric dietician
Neonatal speech and language therapist Psychotherapist
Outreach physiotherapist Ophthalmologist
Safeguarding midwife
Hearing screeners
Training and Education
Mandatory training
Domestic Violence
Child protection
Neonatal life support (NLS)
Neonatal high dependency and intensive care course
Neonatal and special care course
Mentorship
Enhanced Neonatal Practice.
IV Cannulation and administration
Advanced neonatal nurse practitioner training (MSc Advanced clinical practice neonatal studies)
Facilities

Staff has access to a changing room. There is a fully equipped staff room with tea and coffee making facilities and a microwave oven which supports the needs of the staff for working 12. 5 hour shifts. There are lockers available for secure storage of personal items.

There are two offices available for staff. One on the ward for nursing staff and 1 further office is adjacent to the waiting room for medical staff, AHP, and the practice facilitator. Each office is equipped with computers.
Prior to discharge home parents can have use one of the two bedrooms which has ensuite facilities. These rooms are also used for parents of unwell infants who wish to remain on the unit.
There is a dedicated room for hearing and ophthalmology screening.

There is a separate breastfeeding room for mothers to express their breast milk Portable expressing pumps are also available for bedside use should they wish. Curtains are provided around each special care nursery cot space for privacy while feeding.

Parents have access to a sitting room, waiting room and kitchen. The kitchen has hot drink and snack making facilities and microwave. The waiting room has a child friendly seating area. Free parking for parents is also offered from admission. Non secure personal items can be stored in the draws under the cots or incubators. Lockers are available for parental use for more valuable personal items.
There is a designated room for medical staff to share sensitive information with parents or provide counselling.
Infection prevention
The service will be delivered in accordance with the Trust's Infection Prevention Policies.
Contingency
Multiple birth plans for number greater than twins.
Escalation policy for bed and staffing shortages.
Use of Equipment library if equipment shortage.
Battery operated ventilator available on the transport incubator if power should fail.
Backup generator if there is a failure in the electricity supply.
All monitoring, pumps and infusion devices have battery back ups
If PACS was unavailable, hard copies of x-rays would be available.
Blood gas machine available on labour ward.
Monitoring and audit
Audit of compliance with this guideline should be considered on an annual basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy. As part of the directorate audit work
planning process, the directorate audit lead will liaise with appropriate staff to

prioritise audit activity including audit of compliance with clinical guidelines. Where patient safety incidents or complaints highlight non-compliance with this document, the directorate audit lead should be informed and where appropriate an audit
undertaken.

The risk management lead will review all risk event forms and complaints. Any immediate training or educational issues relating to lack of compliance with this guideline will be addressed on a one to one basis.

The findings of the audit will be reported to the Risk Management Group and an action plan developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group on a monthly basis.
There are clinical governance processes in place such as:
Women and Children's Divisional Governance meeting- monthly Perinatal MDT meeting – monthly
Perinatal Mortality & Morbidity meeting – monthly (Feed into quarterly) Trust Patient Safety meeting- monthly
Paediatric Audit meeting – quarterly
Unplanned Admissions to NNU meeting – ad hoc
Safety Huddle meeting – daily
Executive Review Group – ad hoc
Representation attends quarterly Clinical Oversight Group meetings which includes network governance.
Guideline management
Clinical guidelines are in place for the care and management of babies on NNU. Guidelines are consistent with current network and national guidelines. They can be found on the trust Intranet site.

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills and framework, staffs are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Paediatric Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Paediatric Practice Steering Group and appropriate Neonatal Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
This Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 5)
References
Association for Children's Palliative Care (ACT), A Neonatal Pathway for Babies with Palliative Care Needs, 2009
British Association of Perinatal Medicine (BAPM), Service standards for hospital providing neonatal care. rd edition, August 2010
British Association of Perinatal Medicine (BAPM), Categories of care, August 2011.
Department of Health (2009) Toolkit for High Quality Neonatal Services. Available online  http://www.neonatal.org.uk/documents/4650.pdf
National Service Framework for Children, Young People and Maternity Services
October 2004.
Palliative Care (Supportive and End of Life Care). A Framework for Clinical Practice in Perinatal Medicine. Report of the Working Group, August 2010
Neonatal unit clinical operational policy / 09099 /4.0
Neonatal unit clinical operational policy / 09099 /4.0
Appendix 1: Threshold for transfer out
Appendix 2: Categories of care
INTENSIVE CARE
General principle
This is care provided for babies who are the most unwell or unstable and have the greatest needs in relation to staff skills and staff to patient ratios.
Definition of Intensive Care Day
Any day where a baby receives any form of mechanical respiratory support via a tracheal tube
BOTH non-invasive ventilation (e.g. nasal CPAP, SIPAP, BIPAP, vapotherm) and Parenteral Nutrition.
Day of surgery (including laser therapy for ROP)
Day of death
Any day receiving any of the following:
Presence of an umbilical arterial line
Presence of an umbilical venous line
Presence of a peripheral arterial line
Insulin infusion
Presence of a chest drain
Exchange transfusion
Therapeutic hypothermia
Prostaglandin infusion
Presence of replogle tube
Presence of epidural catheter
Presence of silo for gastroschisis
Presence of external ventricular drain
Dialysis (any type)
HIGH DEPENDENCY CARE General principle
This is care provided for babies who require highly skilled staff but where the ratio of nurse to patient is less than intensive care.
Definition of High Dependency Care Day
Any day where a baby does not fulfil the criteria for intensive care where any of the following apply:
Any day where a baby receives any form of non-invasive respiratory support (e.g. nasal CPAP, SIPAP, BIPAP, HHFNC)
Any day receiving any of the following:
parenteral nutrition
continuous infusion of drugs (except prostaglandin &/or insulin)
presence of a central venous or long line (PICC)
presence of a tracheostomy
presence of a urethral or suprapubic catheter
presence of trans-anastomotic tube following oesophageal atresia repair
presence of NP airway/nasal stent
observation of seizures / CF monitoring
barrier nursing
ventricular tap
SPECIAL CARE
General principle
Special care is provided for babies who require additional care delivered by the neonatal service but do not require either Intensive or High Dependency care.
Definition of Special Care Day
Any day where a baby does not fulfil the criteria for intensive or high dependency care and requires any of the following:
oxygen by nasal cannula
feeding by nasogastric, jejunal tube or gastrostomy
continuous physiological monitoring (excluding apnoea monitors only)
care of a stoma
presence of IV cannula
baby receiving phototherapy
special observation of physiological variables at least 4 hourly
TRANSITIONAL CARE
General principle

Transitional care can be delivered in two service models, within a dedicated transitional care ward or within a postnatal ward. In either case the mother must be resident with her baby and providing care. Care above that needed normally is provided by the mother with support from a midwife/healthcare professional who needs no specialist neonatal training. Examples include low birth-weight babies, babies who are on a stable reducing programme of opiate withdrawal for Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome and babies requiring a specific treatment that can be administered on a post-natal ward, such as antibiotics or phototherapy.
Neonatal unit clinical operational policy / 09099 /4.0

What are you proposing to change?
Full review of guideline for document control process
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Full review, addition to include the transitional care for neonatal babies on the Postnatal ward and align to new trust format
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
